DEAR DIARY:
Eagle Rock Lookout is the highest point above the Oranges and Montclair, with a spectacular view of New York City and the harbor.
On a recent stopover I noticed a solitary woman standing at the edge, holding a bright balloon with the words, ''I Love You.''
She let it go, and as it floated up into the blue she started to cry. It drifted off, and she slowly walked to her car and drove away.
PETER H. SECKEL
We recently went to Newark International Airport so we could fly out West to visit our children. After a plane cancellation and a six-hour wait, we were finally on our way.
My husband, who loves Chinese food -- and in another life was probably Asian -- naturally pre-ordered an Asian meal. Sure enough he was served his boxed lunch, which was labeled ''Asian Delite.''
Salivating, he opened it to find a ham-and-cheese sandwich with orange juice. I wondered if there was an Asian on the plane who ordered an ''American Meal'' and received teriyaki and green tea.
HARRIET LEBOWITZ
THE GARDEN (OF EDEN) STATE
Lazing on the Jersey Shore
With a Jersey tomato --
Who could ask for anything more
Than being a conch potato?
EDMUND CONTI
I was right behind the woman and the little girl as they entered Willowbrook Mall.
''It's over,'' the child cried.
''What's over?'' the woman asked.
''The sidewalk sale,'' the child answered.
The woman then explained: ''No, honey. It just started today.''
''Then why are all the sidewalks gone?'' the child asked.
She had a point.
AUDREY CORN

Those of us who ride New Jersey Transit's Midtown Direct know that platforms are announced about five minutes before departure because of a shortage of tracks. Like so many others, I mill around in the concourse and then run to the track as soon as it is posted to avoid having to stand up for my entire trip to Summit.
Yet every day, by the time I get to the train, the seats are almost all taken.
Finally, I drew up the courage to ask the conductor what other passengers knew that I did not.
''It's simple,'' he said. ''They all know I work the same train every day, so they wait until they see me come out of the conductors' waiting room and then follow me to the track.''
PAUL S. NADLER
(Hint: The 5:18 leaves on Track 4 about 90 per cent of the time.)
SHORE FEVER (With apologies to John Masefield)
I must go down to the shore again
where the land meets the sea and sky
And all I need is a beach badge
and a parking space nearby
And some sunscreen and a blanket
to spread in a clearing
And some dark shades so the sun bathers
won't catch me leering.
I must go down to the shore again
for the ocean is in my blood
Where all I need is a beach chair
and a cooler of Coors or Bud
And a beach umbrella
and a boom box blaring
And a laptop and a cell phone
to check how the Nasdaq's faring.
BOB McKENTY
